text: In mathematics, divergence is a differential operator that takes a vector field and turns it into a scalar field. In a vector field, each point of the field is associated with a vector; in a scalar field, each point of the field is associated with a scalar. The divergence tells us how much the vector field is "radiating" outward or inward at a point. Given a vector field \mathbf{F}, the divergence of \mathbf{F} can be written as \operatorname{div} \mathbf{F} or abla \cdot \mathbf{F}. Here, abla (pronounced "del") is the gradient and \cdot is the dot product operation. Divergence is used to formulate Maxwell's equations and the continuity equation. == Related pages == * Curl * Vector calculus == References == Category:Mathematical analysis Category:Calculus
